bibl.title: Account of the Governor's Perquisites to September 11, 1727

div1.p: Robert Carter lists all of the income received between July 22, 1726, and September 11, 1727, to which the colony's governor, George Hamilton, Lord Orkney, was entitled to one half.

div1.head: Account of the Governor's Perquisites to September 11, 1727
div1.p:
The Accot. of the Govr's: Perquisites
from the 22d of July 1726 to the
11th: of Sepr. 1727———
Marriage & Ordy: Lycen: as per the respec***
-tive County Courts Clks Accots. Currt 268 9 11
Money— — — —***
Seals— — — — 24 - -
92 Barrells of Corn at 7/ 32 4 -
£ 324 13 11
Discount 15 perCt: to make it Sterling—-42 7 1
*282 6 10
The Sevl. Naval Officers Accots. Sterling 383 17 9
666 4 7
Dr. Cr.
1727 The Right honble: the Earl of Orkney
* £ S D* £ S D
To my Exchange on Mr. Dawkins}*** By the Mojety of the***
Sent his LdShip in May last} 100** above Perquisites 333 2 3
Decr. 12th: To my Exchange on 116}*******
William Dawkins of Lond} 233 2 3****
*333 2 3****
1728 July 8th
To pd my Lord Orkney
my Exch: on W. Dawkins 30 . 17 . 3
1729 June 28th
To my Exch on Dawkins}
to my Lord Orkney} 2 . 13 . 4
366.13"6

div1.head: NOTES
div1.note: Source copy consulted: Robert Carter letter book, 1727 May-1728 July, Robert Carter Papers (acc. no. 3807), Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia.
At the foot of the page, a different clerk's hand (displayed in green) has added the notes about payments made to Lord Orkney for the exchange charges in 1728 and 1729.
All cells in the tables above containing an "*" are empty in the original. The asterisk was inserted to force all the lines of the cell to appear because browsers do not properly display empty cells.

[1] George Douglas-Hamilton (1666-1737), first earl of Orkney, a distinguished general in the British army, was rewarded in part for his service by being given by Queen Anne the sinecure of governor of Virginia in 1710, a title he held until his death in 1737. He never visited the colony but sent a succession of deputies as lieutenant governors. (Lawrence B. Smith. "Hamilton, George, first earl of Orkney" in Oxford Dictionary of National Biography)
[2] A moiety is "a half, one of two equal parts." (Oxford English Dictionary Online)

note.hi: This text, originally posted in 2003, was revised May 9, 2014, to strengthen the footnotes and modern language version text.
